questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker presents with intermittent chest pain, left arm pain, and ptosis, along with a month-long history of unintentional weight loss. His chest X-ray shows a mass at the left lung apex with adjacent rib destruction. Further imaging, which shows high uptake within the tumor, was performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Small cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the imaging findings points towards diagnosis of Pancoast tumour(superior sulcus tumour).

Pancoast’s tumour is a rare form of lung cancer that originates at the apex of the lung. It has a unique presentation due to the stellate ganglion, chest wall and brachial plexus involvement.

It can invade the brachial plexus (C8 and T1 commonly), resulting in a radicular distribution of pain along the ulnar nerve. Invasion of the stellate ganglion results in Horner’s syndrome which presents with ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, enophthalmos, and anhidrosis. Shoulder and chest pain on the same side can result from the invasion into the chest wall and the 1st and/or 2nd ribs. Local spread, if involving the trachea or esophagus can result in dyspnea or dysphagia. 

Investigations:

  • MRI > CT is the investigation of choice for superior sulcus tumour/ Pancoast tumour.
  • FDG-PET scan shows high uptake by the tumour cells. FDG is taken up by all metabolizing cells but more avidly by cancer cells.
  • Bronchoscopy can be done in endobronchial tumours to obtain a tissue diagnosis.

Management is summarized in the flowchart as shown below.

Other options:

Option A: Small cell lung carcinoma is a highly malignant tumour that has a strong link to cigarette smoking. Tumours may arise in major bronchi or in the periphery of the lung. The presence of neurosecretory granules and the expression of neuroendocrine markers, such as CD56 and chromogranin, indicate that the tumour is derived from neuroendocrine progenitor cells found in the lining of the bronchial epithelium.

Option B: Bronchial carcinoid tumours typically arise as central masses that grow into finger-like polypoid masses that frequently protrude into the bronchus lumen. They are associated with features of carcinoid syndrome like diarrhoea, flushing and wheezing. Biopsy would show clusters of neuroendocrine cells and positive chromogranin A staining.

Option D: Adenocarcinoma of the lung is the most common form of lung cancer. It is an invasive malignant epithelial tumour with glandular differentiation. It originates from the terminal bronchiole and is typically found in the periphery. Tumour cells frequently "crawl" along normal-appearing alveolar septa in a lepidic pattern of spread near the tumour's periphery.

questions.text: The following X-rays depicts_______?
questions.solution:
The given x ray depicts Melorheostosis.

Melorheostosis: It is also known as Leri's Disease. It is a rare mesenchymal dysplasia manifesting as regions of sclerosis of cortices with a characteristic dripping wax appearance or flowing candle wax appearance. The presentation is usually monostotic and unilateral. Symptoms include pain, deformity, skin and circulation problems and contractures.

Osteopoikilosis is a benign autosomal dominant sclerosing bone dysplasia with multiple bone islands in a peri-articular distribution in tubular bones, pelvis and scapulae. They are typically bilateral and symmetrical.

Osteopathia striata, is a rare, benign dysplasia of bone with radiographically prominent vertical striations involving the epiphysis and metaphysis of tubular bones. It is typically asymptomatic, although there can be associated joint discomfort.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with neck webbing and a low posterior hairline. On examination, she has restricted neck mobility and elevated scapulae on both sides. X-ray neck findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an xray neck showing fusion of C6, C7, and T1 vertebrae suggests a diagnosis of Klippel-Feil syndrome. 

Klippel-Feil syndrome is a developmental disorder caused by failure of segmentation of the cervical somites during the 3rd to 8th week of embryogenesis, resulting in fusion of at least two cervical segments. Congenital fusion can occur at any level in the cervical spine but mostly occurs in the upper cervical spine. It is sometimes associated with fetal alcohol syndrome.

The classical triad of children with Klippel-Feil syndrome is a short neck with various degrees of neck webbing, low posterior hairline and limited neck mobility. 

It is associated with other skeletal and extraskeletal abnormalities such as scoliosis, renal abnormalities, (most commonly unilateral renal agenesis), Sprengel deformity(unilateral congenital elevation of scapula), deafness and congenital heart disease such as ventricular septal defect(VSD). Hand abnormalities include syndactyly, thumb hypoplasia and extra digits.

Symptoms are mainly restriction of neck movements in the involved segments, hypermobility of the adjacent segments and neurological deficits. For asymptomatic patients, treatment is conservative with parents warned about contact sports since sudden neurological compromise can occur after minor trauma. Children with symptoms may need cervical fusion. 

Other options -

Option A - Poland syndrome is a sporadic condition characterised by unilateral hypoplasia of the whole upper limb girdle including the shoulder and chest wall(ribs, pectoral muscles, breast tissue, nipple). The corresponding hand shows brachydactyly(small digits), syndactyly(fused digits) and symphalangism(fused phalanges, absent interphalangeal joints). 

Option C - Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder characterized by an XO aneuploidy in a female with short stature, webbing of the neck due to resolution of cystic hygroma, low posterior highline and a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. Other features include streak ovaries causing amenorrhea and infertility with a normal vagina, uterus, and prepubertal female genitalia. There is no fusion of cervical spine or bilateral elevated scapulae as in Klippel-Feil syndrome.

Option D - Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis(DISH), also known as Forestier’s disease is a common condition seen in late middle-aged/ elderly males characterised by hyperostosis seen at multiple sites, but mainly in the spine at enthesis sites (where tendons and ligaments attach to the bone). Most commonly involves T7 to T12. Cervical and lumbar hyperostosis may also be seen. It is not a congenital condition as well as the absence of bilateral elevated scapulae, neck webbing and low posterior hairline differentiates from Klippel Feil syndrome. Patients might even be asymptomatic and the condition may be found incidentally.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown by the arrow.
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the common hepatic duct.

ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography. A side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla. It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree. It can be both therapeutic and diagnostic.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is performed using a side-viewing fibreoptic duodenoscope.

The ampulla of Vater is intubated, and contrast is injected into the biliary and pancreatic ducts to display the anatomy radiologically.

The most common significant complication is acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: A young man presents with seizures that are resistant to medication. The skull X-ray findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows bracket calcification which is seen in the lipoma of the corpus callosum.

Majority of the lipomas arise near the corpus callosum. These tumors have marginal calcification where they merge with the adjacent cortical tissues. This gives rise to the characteristic bracket appearance. Intracranial lipomas are asymptomatic. Epileptic seizures are common and are occasionally refractory to anticonvulsant treatment.

Other options:

Option A- Sturge–Weber syndrome shows the following features:

  • Facial port-wine stain along the course of the trigeminal nerve
  • Ipsilateral venous angiomas in the cortical leptomeninges
  • Mental retardation
  • Seizures, hemiplegia
  • Skull radio-opacities i.e tram track calcification.

 Below image shows Tram track calcification

Option B- Tuberous sclerosis shows cortical tubers and calcification of ependymal nodules in the wall of ventricles. 

Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder caused by mutations in the TSC1 (chromosome 9) or TSC2 (chromosome 16) genes, which code for hamartin and tuberin respectively. 

Tuberous sclerosis presents usually at a young age. Patients may have retinal hamartomas, cardiac rhabdomyoma, renal angiomyolipomas, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas. The patients present with characteristic cutaneous signs. The first cutaneous sign that develops is the ash leaf macule, which is a macular hypomelanotic patch, commonly seen on the lower back. Another cutaneous manifestation is the shagreen patch, which is a hypermelanotic nevus. It is located in the lumbosacral region. The characteristic bumps that develop on the face are called adenoma sebaceum or facial angiofibromas.

The image below shows the characteristic ash leaf macule.

The below image shows adenoma sebaceum.

 

The below image shows Shagreen patch 

Option C- Meningioma on X-Ray shows calcification, hyperostosis of adjacent bone, and increased vascular markings, it is usually seen falx. Imaging shows the presence of a dural tail sign.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient presents with fever, chills, and a cough with sputum production. His blood pressure is 150/88 mmHg, pulse rate is 110 bpm, respiratory rate is 18, and SpO2 is 88% on room air. An X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation, along with chest X-ray findings showing lobar involvement, suggest a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia.

Clinical features include acute onset fever, cough (with or without sputum production), and shortness of breath. In some cases, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypoxemia, or increased work of breathing may be present on physical examination.

Diagnosis can be made using a chest X-ray. The presence of an infiltrate on a plain chest radiograph is considered the gold standard for diagnosing pneumonia. Radiographic findings consistent with the diagnosis of CAP include lobar consolidations, interstitial infiltrates, and/or cavitations. CT chest is used for better resolution or if chest X-ray was non-diagnostic. Blood and sputum cultures are obtained to guide the antibiotic regimen.

Other options:

Option A: Pleural effusion may present with dyspnea, pleuritic pain, dry cough, and associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, oedema, and ascites depending on the aetiology. On examination, there may be tachypnea, dullness on percussion and decreased/absent breath sounds at the base(s).

Option C: Coal worker's pneumoconiosis (CWP) is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to coal dust. It is seen in people working in mines. It presents small opacities in the upper lobe of the lungs. Complicated CWP has nodules ≥1 cm in diameter generally confined to the upper half of the lungs. 

Option D: Silicosis is an occupational disease and is caused by exposure to silica. It is seen in people who work in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, and quarrying. It presents as small rounded opacities in the upper lobe. There may be calcification of hilar lymph nodes which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. HRCT will show a characteristic crazy paving pattern. The image is given below

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with chronic back pain, easy fatigability, and a history of multiple urinary tract infections over the past 3 months. His ESR is elevated, and a skull X-ray is shown below. Which of the following investigations would be useful for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is indicative of multiple myeloma, and a useful diagnostic test would be serum electrophoresis.

Multiple myeloma involves a malignant proliferation of plasma cells, resulting in excessive production of abnormal immunoglobulins, causing a spike called the M band in Serum Electrophoresis.

The given image demonstrates a sharp peak ("church spire” or M band) in the gamma globulin region. This is characteristically seen in a patient with multiple myeloma.

 

Certain common diseases and their electrophoretic pattern:

Condition  Electrophoretic pattern
Chronic infections Smooth increase in gamma globulins
Multiple myeloma Gamma globulin part is increased (M BAND)
Liver cirrhosis Reduced albumin and compensatory increase in globulin
Primary immune deficiency Gamma globulin reduced
α1 antitrypsin deficiency α1 band is thin and even lost sometimes

 Multiple myelomas: 

  • Malignant neoplasm of plasma cells characterized by:
  • Presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chains in the serum and urine
  • Bone destruction (lytic lesions)
  • Disease of older adults, with a peak age of incidence of 65 to 70 years
  • Signs and symptoms
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Pathologic fractures/lytic bone lesions
    • Renal failure
    • Anemia
    • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
    • Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
    • Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
    • Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20%plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
    • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation.)
  • Plasma cell tumors are positive for CD138

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to you with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The X-ray appearance of his left hip joint is shown in the below image. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and trethowan's sign seen in the x-ray are suggestive of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

The Klein line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis. In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign.

Slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SCFE) occurs during a period of rapid growth with the average age of presentation around 12 years.

Risk factors: Obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Patients with SCFE typically present in the rapid growth phase of adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Other radiological findings include:

  • Wide or irregular physis with loss of the anterior head-neck concavity
  • Sharp metaphyseal border of the head
  • Loss of total epiphyseal height
  • Steel sign (Metaphyseal blanch sign) - The posteriorly displaced femoral epiphysis overlaps over the metaphysis causing a crescent-shaped area of increased density on the AP radiograph.
  • Capener’s sign –the metaphysis displaces laterally, worsening the slip and causes a reduction in the double-density crescent created by the overlap of the posterior acetabulum and proximal metaphysis on the AP radiograph.
  • Southwick angle – The angle between the line drawn perpendicular to the physis and a line parallel to the femoral shaft. As slip worsens, the Southwick angle will increase. It is measured on the frog lateral X-ray view.

Other options:

Perthes disease:

It is characterized by idiopathic avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. This condition commonly affects children of 4-8 years of age. The child has pain in the hip while performing passive movements. The radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodeling.

Developmental Dysplasia of the hip: It is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. This condition is more common in females. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip are decreased. X-ray shows a broken Shenton's line and the femoral head lies in the upper and outer quadrants formed by Hilgenreiner’s line and Perkin’s line.

The image given below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner's line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrant formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

Ankylosing spondylitis: It is a chronic progressive inflammatory condition affecting the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton. It is commonly seen in young male adults and they typically present with an insidious onset back pain that improves with exercise. The earliest radiological finding is erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints and the characteristic late sign is the bamboo-spine appearance.

X-ray showing bamboo-spine appearance-

questions.text:
The barium swallow images of different conditions of the esophagus are given below. Which of the following images represents the condition characterized by the manometric findings given below?
  1. Normal integrated relaxation pressure in manometry.
  2. Premature spastic contractions.
  3. Distal contractile integral (DCI) >450 mmHg.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given features is diffuse esophageal spasm (DES)/ Distal esophageal spasm. Image 2 showing a rosary bead or corkscrew appearance of the esophagus on a barium swallow represents the condition.

DES is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus that manifests as dysphagia and chest pain that may radiate to the jaw, arms, and upper back. It is more common in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. Muscular hypertrophy and degeneration of the branches of the vagus nerve in the esophagus are seen in this condition. Oesophageal contractions are repetitive, simultaneous, and of high amplitude. 

The diagnosis of DES is made by radiographic and manometric studies. Manometric findings are:

  • Normal integrated relaxation pressure in manometry.
  • Premature spastic contractions.
  • Distal contractile integral (DCI) >450 mmHg.

On barium swallow, a rosary bead or corkscrew appearance is seen. It indicates tertiary contractions and advanced disease.

Treatment is with long-acting nitrates, calcium channel-blocking agents, sedatives, and anticholinergics. Bougie dilation of the esophagus relieves dysphagia in many patients. Intrasphincteric injection of botulinum toxin has been tried. Surgery is indicated for patients who fail to respond to medical or endoscopic therapy.

 
Other options:

Image A: Achalasia cardia is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis. It affects men more than women. A barium swallow shows the presence of a characteristic bird's beak appearance. It is shown below.

Image C: Feline esophagus refers to the transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is almost always associated with active gastroesophageal reflux. 1-2 mm thick, horizontal folds are seen around the entire circumference following reflux.

Image D: Zenker diverticulum is the most common of all the esophageal diverticula. It is much more commoner in men, after age 60. Patients present with dysphagia, regurgitation, and halitosis. Barium study shows the presence of a diverticulum. It is shown in the image below, indicated by the red arrow.

questions.text: A worker from the cement industry got a chest X-ray as a part of his routine health check-up. What could cause the findings in the given chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
The findings in the chest X-ray suggest asbestosis.

The given X-ray shows irregular opacities, which appear to be pleural thickenings i.e., pleural plaques. The sign along with a history of working in the cement industry suggests a diagnosis of asbestosis. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes. 

Workers in the cement, shipping, and textile industries are at a higher risk of developing asbestosis. Asbestos tends to involve the pleura first. The earliest manifestation is benign asbestosis-related pleural effusion. With time, the plaques are calcified resulting in the formation of thick pleural plaques. The pleural thickenings can be seen on the X-ray. This is the “holly leaf sign”.

Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years). They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

Other options:

Option A: Berylliosis (chronic beryllium disease) commonly occurs in workers exposed to beryllium, typically in industries like electronics or aerospace, not in cement. On imaging, it usually presents with diffuse interstitial lung disease, nodules, or enlarged hilar lymph nodes.

Option B: Tuberculosis (TB) often appears as upper lobe infiltrates, cavitation, or miliary patterns on imaging.

Option D: Silicosis, often seen in industries such as mining or quarrying, presents with nodular opacities, especially in the upper lobes, and may have eggshell calcifications in the hilar lymph nodes.

questions.text: A newborn developed tachypnea and grunting immediately after birth. On examination, the baby was cyanotic, with a scaphoid abdomen. A chest radiograph was taken, which is shown below. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing herniation of the bowel loops into the chest and absence of bowel loops in the abdomen are suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Bag and mask ventilation is to be avoided in the management of this baby.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect of the diaphragm. Malformation of the diaphragm allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity, hindering proper lung formation and resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia. The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia and in most cases involving the left side. CDH is a life-threatening pathology in infants and a major cause of morbidity and mortality due to two complications: pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension.

Babies with CDH present with respiratory distress characterized by tachypnea, grunting, use of accessory muscles, and cyanosis. They may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter. Auscultation of the chest may reveal bowel sounds with reduced breath sounds.

Diagnosis: A chest radiograph and nasogastric tube passage can confirm the diagnosis of CDH. Prenatal diagnosis can be made using ultrasonography between 16 to 24 weeks of gestation.

Treatment:

The immediate step in the management is the naso- or orogastric tube placement for decompression. The airway is to be secured with endotracheal intubation (option B) and respiratory distress is stabilised. Bag and mask ventilation may increase the abdominal distension and limit the expansion of the hypoplastic lungs. Hence, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided.

Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) (option A) and high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (Option D) have been used as a part of the ventilation strategy to support respiratory failure. The main goal is to maintain oxygenation to the lungs and carbon dioxide washout without causing volutrauma.

Surgical repair of the defect is to be considered at least 48 hours after stabilization and resolution of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text:
Following appearance in IVP is diagnostic of ______.

IVP: intravenous pyelography
questions.solution:
The image depicts the maiden waist sign seen in retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Maiden waist deformity is the appearance of the deviation of bilateral ureters. This typically occurs in retroperitoneal fibrosis. In this condition, there is a medial drawing of the ureter due to the deposition of fibrous tissue in the lumbosacral junction. Due to the involvement of both ureters, the course of the medially-drawn ureters is said to have an appearance of a narrow waist maiden, thus giving the name.

Other options:

Option A: In the retrocaval ureter, the ureter abnormally loops behind the IVC, causing a characteristic S-shaped or fishhook appearance.

Option C: Medullary sponge kidney is a congenital disorder characterized by dilated renal tubules, which leads to a paintbrush appearance of the renal papillae on IVP due to small calculi in the collecting ducts. 

Option D: Multicystic dysplastic kidney is a congenital anomaly where the kidney is replaced by multiple cysts of varying sizes, and the ureter may be atretic or absent.

questions.text: A post–myocardial infarction patient presented to the emergency room with sudden-onset breathlessness and cough with frothy sputum. The patient's chest x-ray, on PA view, revealed the following findings. Identify the lines.
questions.solution:
The above clinical features are suggestive of pulmonary edema due to left-sided heart failure, and Kerley B lines are characteristic findings seen in this setting. Kerley B lines are horizontal subpleural lines, 1 cm in length and 1–3 mm in thickness, usually seen in the middle or lower zone of the lungs. 

Radiological signs of left-sided heart failure:

  • Cardiomegaly - Enlargement of the cardiac silhouette
  • Kerley B lines - Horizontal lines in the periphery of the lower posterior lung fields
  • Upper lobe pulmonary venous congestion 
  • Interstitial edema

 Types of Kerley lines:  

  • Kerley A lines:
    • They are deep septal lines and are longer than Kerley B lines.
    • They radiate from the periphery to the central portion of the lungs.
    • HRCT is the best modality for the demonstration of Kerley A lines.
    • They indicate severe pulmonary edema.
  • Kerley B lines:
    • These are thin lines 1–2 cm in length in the periphery of the lung.
    • They are perpendicular to the pleural surface and extend out to it.
    • They represent thickened subpleural interlobular septa.
    • They are usually seen at the lung bases.
  • Kerley C lines :
    • They occur due to the thickening of the lung parenchymal interstitium.
    • They have a reticular pattern on chest radiography.
  • Kerley D lines 
    •  They are exactly the same as Kerley B lines, except that they are seen on lateral chest radiographs, in the retrosternal air gap.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with complaints of inability to conceive underwent the following investigation. Which of the following is false about the same?

choices.text: The best time to perform it is before ovulation
It is perfomed to detect uterine anomalies
It is the first-line investigation in genital tuberculosis
Premedication can be done with atropine

questions.solution:
The given image shows a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). HSG is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis.

Procedure of HSG:

  • It is best performed in the period between the last day of menses to ovulation, usually on the 9th/10th day of the cycle (option A).
  • 10-15ml radioopaque dye is injected into the uterine cavity via Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter.
  • Fluoroscopy is performed as the dye passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. 
  • If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia into the peritoneum, and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used for the detection of:

  • Tubal block - It can be due to:
    • Strictures - fibrotic block
    • Inspissated amorphous material
    • Tubal spasm - This can occur in apprehensive patients. It is prevented by premedication with atropine and analgesia (option D).
  • Uterine anomalies (option B)
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • The feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology.

Contraindications:

  • Genital tract infections, such as genital tuberculosis. This is due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Bleeding
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Allergy to the dye
  • Premenstrual phase:
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with chronic pain and stiffness in the knees. An X-ray of her knee is shown below. The patient is most likely suffering from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient's complaints of chronic joint discomfort and radiograph indicating the presence of subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and narrowing of the joint space strongly imply a diagnosis of osteoarthritis.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage and underlying bone changes. The typical clinical features include chronic joint pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion, as well as radiographic findings of joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis. 

Management of osteoarthritis often involves a combination of non-pharmacological and pharmacological treatments, such as weight management, physical therapy, analgesics, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and intra-articular injections. In severe cases, joint replacement surgery may be considered to alleviate symptoms and improve joint function.

Other options:

Option A: Pseudogout, also known as calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), is a type of arthritis that occurs due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in the joints. It can cause sudden and severe joint pain, swelling, and stiffness. While it can present with joint-specific symptoms, it does not typically manifest with the radiographic findings described in the case, ie subchondral cysts, osteophytes and sclerosis. Patients with pseudogout have chondrocalcinosis as depicted in the image below.

Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the synovial membrane of the joints, leading to joint pain, stiffness, and swelling. While it can cause joint damage and deformity, it often presents with different radiographic findings, including erosions(key hallmark) and periarticular osteopenia. However, it is crucial to note that when treated, patients may develop underlying proliferation and resemble a radiograph of a patient with osteoarthritis, as illustrated in the image below.

Option D: Osteoporosis is a common metabolic bone disease characterized by a diffuse reduction in bone density due to a decrease in bone mass. It is typically asymptomatic until fractures occur. These fractures are commonly low trauma in nature, defined as a fall from standing height or less. A DEXA scan is the investigation of choice in diagnosing osteoporosis and the results are reported in terms of T-score, and a score of -2.5 or lower is defined as osteoporosis.

questions.text: The urinary bladder shown in the MCU image below is commonly diagnostic of _______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a pine cone bladder or Christmas tree bladder, in which the bladder is elongated and pointed with a thickened trabeculated wall. It is typically seen in severe neurogenic bladder.

Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination.

There are five types of neurogenic bladder based on the site of the lesion.

  1. Sensory neurogenic bladder: posterior columns of the spinal cord or afferent tracts leading from the bladder
  2. Motor paralytic bladder: damage to motor neurons of the bladder
  3. Uninhibited neurogenic bladder: incomplete spinal cord lesions above s2 or cerebral cortex or cerebropontine axis lesions
  4. Reflex neurogenic bladder: complete spinal cord lesions above s2 - may lead to pine cone bladder

Autonomous neurogenic bladder: conus or cauda equina lesions.

Other options:

Option A: Bladder diverticula appear as outpouchings or sacs arising from the bladder wall, which may be visible on an MCU as small, round, or oval outpouchings.

Option B: A cystic pelvic mass would generally be seen as a discrete cystic structure separate from the bladder.

Option D: Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) involves the abnormal backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureters. On an MCU, VUR would show contrast ascending into the ureters .

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with multiple brown coffee coloured  skin rashes. She has increased uptake on bone scans over the femur, skull, and ribs. Biochemical parameters are abnormal. She also has a history of hypothyroidism. An X-ray of her femur is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray shows the bending of the femur known as Shepherd's crook deformity. It is seen in fibrous dysplasia of the proximal femur. 

Her symptoms are a part of McCune Albright syndrome. McCune Albright syndrome presents as a triad of cafe-au-lait spots (cutaneous pigmentation), polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and precocious puberty. It is also associated with multiple endocrinopathies like hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, etc. The locus of involvement is the GNAS1 gene. 

Cutaneous pigmentation is more prominent on the side with severe bone involvement. Fibrous dysplasia is a condition that affects bone development and is characterized by the replacement of the bone with fibrous tissue. The patient presents with a progressive limb deformity or a fracture through a previously asymptomatic lesion. The presentation often occurs in the second decade. Other symptoms include nonspecific bone pain, tenderness, and swelling in the affected area. The commonly involved sites are the proximal femur, tibia, pelvis, and foot.

Radiological findings include:
  • Well-defined, expansile intramedullary lesions
  • Hazy ground glass appearance is seen in the majority of cases
  • Shepherd's crook deformity - expansion with marked varus in the proximal femur.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of heart surgery now presents with the chest X-ray shown below. What is the finding indicated by the '?' on the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image shows a prosthetic mitral valve and a pacemaker also in place.

Prosthetic heart valves are common. The most commonly replaced are aortic and mitral valves.

Replacements may be tissue or metallic valves.

In recent times, aortic valves in select circumstances are being replaced via a transcatheter approach, called transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI) from a femoral artery approach.

Prosthetic valves are subdivided into two categories -mechanical and bioprosthetic

  • Mechanical valves
    • ball cage valves
    • tilting disk valves
  • Bioprosthetic valves
    • homografts
    • heterografts
    • stented
    • stentless

Transesophageal echocardiography is the modality of choice to assess the status of a prosthetic heart valve after placement of a valve.

Complications:

  • Obstruction
    • maybe due to thrombus or pannus
  • Infective endocarditis
    • with or without valvular vegetation or paravalvular abscess
  • Paravalvular regurgitation
  • Valve failure
    • mechanical failure in mechanical valves
    • degeneration of a biological valve
  • Hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A woman who underwent cholecystectomy now presents with abdominal pain one month later. An erect abdominal X-ray was taken, and the image is shown below. Which of the following options best describes the condition?
questions.solution:
The x-ray shows a pair of surgical scissors left behind in the abdomen after surgery. The offense comes under res ipsa loquitur. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed.

"Res ipsa loquitur" means "the thing or fact speaks for itself." The negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence. He has to merely state what according to him was the negligent act.

This doctrine applies to both civil and criminal negligence. All of the following conditions should be fulfilled for this doctrine:

  • In the absence of negligence, there would not have been any injury usually
  • The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.
  • The patient was not a part of contributory negligence.

Other options:

Option A: Novus actus interveniens - A person is responsible not only for his actions but also for the logical consequences of those actions. This principle applies to cases of assault and accidental injury.

Option C: Res judicata - If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same in another legal proceeding, based on the same set of facts. Multiple appeals cannot be made. 

Option D: The principle of respondeat superior is used to explain vicarious liability, which explains that the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with chronic low-back ache underwent an oblique X-ray of the LS spine. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the X-ray given, there is a break in the region of pars interarticularlis of the L4 vertebra, which appears like a beheaded Scottish terrier sign. This is diagnostic of spondylolisthesis. 

Spondylolisthesis is the anterior displacement of a vertebra over another, usually at the lower lumbar spine. Occasionally, the displacement is backward (retrolisthesis). It is characterized by chronic back pain and lumbar lordosis. Normally, spinous processes of adjacent vertebrae can be palpated on the back smoothly. In spondylolisthesis, a step-off or step sign can be felt over the spinous process at the affected level.

The Beheaded Scottish terrier sign on the X-ray is diagnostic. It is due to a break in the pars interarticularis of the vertebra. The investigation of choice in the case of spondylolysis and spondylolisthesis is an oblique view X-ray of the lumbar spine.

Other options:

Option A: Normal spine: The posterior elements of the normal vertebra appear like a 'Scottish terrier dog' and this is known as Scottish terrier sign or Scottie dog sign (see image below).

Option C: In Spondylolysis there is a defect or break in the pars without dislocation. This gives the appearance of Scottish terrier with collar sign as shown in the image below.

Option D: Spinal tuberculosis occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region.
